history.content: There are no enrollment restrictions on any upper div cs course after the end of phase 2.

children.subject: 186/286A combined lecture has an enrollment of 480 students.  Maximum enrollment is 481.  (That just means 1 student dropped between the last automatic processing of the waitlist and now.)   There is more combined capacity in discussion sections than in the lecture. Both the lecture limit and the individual discussion section limit are indeed limits to enrollment.

What is the point of adding sections when you cannot increase the size of students in the lecture? If I have no chance getting into an open section, I don't understand why the department would add it?

The learning experience of the 481 students in the class is improved if the ration of gsi to student in discussion sections is smaller.  That being the case, if the budget is there, a qualified applicant to staff the section exists, and the professor wants to make this happen, then we go ahead and make it happen.  While we certainly wish this benefited others as well, we often do things that benefit some people but not all people.  We of course wish all of our actions could benefit everyone.

ah, I see. I think it would be helpful to a vast number of students if the department advertised this policy, as many students (including myself) have dropped out of more highly enrolled sections with shorter waitlists to add "open" sections with longer waitlists, which ultimately hurts our chances of enrollment if the lecture is not expanded. Thanks.

I can see how this might be helpful and we'll try to remember. I also encourage students to look at the size of the lecture hall and the current enrollment limit for the course as part of what you consider before making changes like this.

Note: The root problems here are weaknesses in the new campus-wide student enrollment system:

1) Similar to telebears, students are unable to see their position on discussion/lab/etc. section waitlists.

2) More to the point, and a new weakness that didn't exist with telebears, students cannot change secondary section selections without dropping to the end of the lecture waitlist. If this were not true, changing discussion section choice would never work to the detriment of an individual student's chances of being enrolled in any particular class.  Students, staff, and perhaps faculty all across campus have brought this to the project team's attention.  It is unclear whether anything will be done to fix this as campus has shared mixed messages in response to concerns raised.

Fingers crossed.
Does this mean that there's no chance we can get into the class now if we're on the waitlist? Even adding myself to an open section won't do me any good then if there's no space in lecture?
Some students will drop; students from the waitlist will move into those spaces.
Why are there people on waitlists for sections with open seats (e.g., http://classes.berkeley.edu/content/2017-spring-compsci-186-001-dis-115)?

CS186: Why are there waitlisted people in sections with open spots?

On the course catalog, there are several sections listed with open seats, yet when I click on them there are people on the waitlist. Should I drop the class and enroll myself in one of the sections with open seats, and lose my lecture waitlist position (which is fairly high, 25ish), or should I just wait it out? I'm not a CS major, but since enrollment isn't impacted anymore it shouldnt matter right? Thanks

history.content: I'm waitlisted for CS 186 and there are open seats in some sections, but there are a bunch of people on the waitlists for those sections too. How can I find out if I, as a declared CS major, can enroll in those sections? I asked the instructors and they referred me here.
history.subject: How to see what types of enrollment restrictions open seats have?
